==Republican convention==

The Republican nomination process for the 2021 elections was the subject of a lengthy and acrimonious debate within the [[Republican Party of Virginia]].<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-gop-governor-vote-counting/2021/04/21/fbb6760c-a2d6-11eb-a774-7b47ceb36ee8_story.html Three Republicans running for Virginia governor wary of vote-counting software], ''Washington Post'' (April 21, 2021).</ref><ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn>{{Cite web|title=Virginia GOP settles on nominating method with May convention looming|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/virginia-gop-settles-on-nominating-method-with-may-convention-looming/|date=April 22, 2021|author=Dean Mirshahi|publisher=WRIC}}</ref> On December 5, 2020, the state Republican Party voted to hold a convention instead of a primary by a vote of 41 to 28.<ref>{{Cite web|title=RPV State Central Committee Meeting;Voted Convention for 2021;Live Updates – Bearing Drift|url=https://bearingdrift.com/2020/12/05/rpv-state-central-committee-meeting-voted-convention-for-2021/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=bearingdrift.com|date=December 5, 2020}}</ref> State Senator [[Amanda Chase]] initially indicated that she would run as an independent,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last1=Oliver|first1=Ned|date=2020-12-05|title=Chase promises to run as independent for governor after Va. GOP opts for convention over primary|url=https://www.virginiamercury.com/2020/12/05/chase-threatens-to-run-as-independent-for-governor-as-va-gop-opts-for-convention-over-primary/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=Virginia Mercury|language=en-US}}</ref> but later decided to seek nomination at the convention. (However, on the day of the convention, she acknowledged that if she did not win the nomination, she may reconsider and run as an independent, although she eventually decided against this.)<ref>{{cite tweet |last=Chase |first=Amanda |author-link=Amanda Chase |user=AmandaChaseVA |number=1391150084377677826 |date=May 8, 2021 |title=If RPV steals this election for Pete I still have plenty of time to run as an independent. Clear corruption by RPV, I will not honor a pledge if the Party cannot run a fair process. |language=en |access-date=June 12, 2021 |archive-url= |archive-date=June 12, 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref> Faced with pressure from the Chase campaign and activists to return to a primary, the state committee debated scrapping the convention on January 23, 2021. These efforts were unsuccessful and the party reaffirmed their decision to hold a convention.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Oliver |first1=Ned |title=Virginia Republicans stick with nominating convention |url=https://www.virginiamercury.com/2021/01/24/virginia-republicans-stick-with-convention-as-messy-fight-continues/ |access-date=January 25, 2021 |work=Virginia Mercury |date=January 24, 2021}}</ref> On February 9, 2021, the Chase campaign sued the Republican Party of Virginia, arguing that the convention is illegal under [[COVID-19]]-related executive orders signed by Governor [[Ralph Northam]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Manchester|first1=Julia|date=February 9, 2021|title=Republican gubernatorial candidate sues Virginia GOP over nominating process|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/538075-republican-state-senator-sues-virginia-gop-over-nominating-process|url-status=live|access-date=February 9, 2021|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}}</ref> The Richmond Circuit Court dismissed the Chase campaign's lawsuit on February 19, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Manzanares|first1=Keyris|date=February 19, 2021|title=Judge blocks Sen. Amanda Chase's lawsuit challenging Virginia GOP nomination plans|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/judge-blocks-sen-amanda-chases-lawsuit-challenging-virginia-gop-nomination-plansw|url-status=live|access-date=February 19, 2021|website=[[WRIC-TV|WRIC]]}}</ref> The Republican Party of Virginia announced on March 26, 2021, that seven gubernatorial candidates had qualified to appear on the convention ballot.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|date=2021-03-26|title=RPV Announces Qualified Convention Candidates|url=https://virginia.gop/rpv-announces-qualified-convention-candidates/|access-date=2021-03-26|website=Republican Party of Virginia|language=en-US}}</ref> On April 11, 2021, the state Republican Party Rules Committee voted to tabulate the ballots by hand; three days later, however, the committee reversed itself and decided to use a vendor's software-based tabulation method.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/>

On April 20, 2021, five candidates (Amanda Chase, Kirk Cox, Sergio de la Peña, Peter Doran, and Glenn Youngkin) participated in a forum at [[Liberty University]] in [[Lynchburg, Virginia|Lynchburg]].<ref name=wric.nom>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/5-republicans-in-virginia-governors-race-make-their-pitch-to-voters-during-liberty-university-forum/|title=Key takeaways from the Republican gubernatorial forum in Lynchburg|date=2021-04-20|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Mirshahi|first=Dean}}</ref> Two candidates, Octavia Johnson and Pete Snyder, did not attend the forum.<ref name=wric.nom/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/republicans-running-for-virginia-governor-appear-at-liberty-university-forum/2021/04/20/b94d408e-a1eb-11eb-a7ee-949c574a09ac_story.html|title=Republicans running for Virginia governor appear at Liberty University forum|date=2021-04-20|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Vozzella|first=Laura}}</ref>

The state Republican convention to select the party's nominees for governor, lieutenant governor, and attorney general took place on May 8, 2021,<ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn/><ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> in "unassembled" format,<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> with ballots to be cast remotely at up to 37 locations statewide<ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn/> using [[instant-runoff voting|ranked-choice voting]].<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> The complex process fueled internal party disputes.<ref name=VozzellaUnorthodox>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-gop-convention/2021/04/04/4bfe8fc4-9228-11eb-a74e-1f4cf89fd948_story.html Unorthodox Republican contest for Virginia governor breeds confusion, suspicion], ''Washington Post'' (April 4, 2021).</ref> Up to 40,000 people were anticipated to become delegates, although not all would necessarily cast votes.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> Local Republican Party leaders control the application process to become a delegate, decide who can participate (voter registration in Virginia does not include a space to indicate party affiliation), and select the convention voting site.<ref name=VozzellaUnorthodox/> In the preceding Virginia Republican gubernatorial convention, 12,000 participated.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/>

[[Orthodox Jewish]] Virginia Republicans asked the party to allow absentee voting for religious reasons (May 8 is on the [[Jewish Sabbath]]), but the State Central Committee initially voted down the request, failing to achieve the 75% supermajority needed to change the rules.<ref>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-republican-convention-orthodox-jews/2021/04/23/3169c904-a442-11eb-85fc-06664ff4489d_story.html Virginia GOP won't let Orthodox Jews vote absentee in Sabbath-day convention], ''Washington Post'' (April 23, 2021).</ref> However, the Virginia GOP ultimately reversed course and allowed those with religious objections to vote in the May 8 convention via absentee ballots. Republican candidates Kirk Cox, Peter Doran, and Glenn Youngkin had criticized the previous decision to not accommodate Orthodox Jews.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/in-reversal-virginia-gop-will-allow-those-with-religious-obligations-to-vote-absentee-in-may-8-convention/|title=In reversal, Virginia GOP will allow those with religious obligations to vote absentee in May 8 convention|date=April 26, 2021}}</ref>

==General election==

On August 26, the Republican Party of Virginia filed a lawsuit to disqualify McAuliffe from appearing on the ballot in November. The suit alleges that McAuliffe did not sign his declaration of candidacy, which is needed to qualify in the primary and general election.<ref name=vgop.lawsuit>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/virginia-republican-party-terry-mcauliffe-lawsuit-governor-ballot-signature-2021-8|title=Virginia GOP files lawsuit to remove Democratic gubernatorial nominee Terry McAuliffe from the November ballot|date=2021-08-28|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> It was found that the declaration of candidacy was missing his signature, although it includes two witnesses' signatures. The suit also alleges the witnesses violated state law by witnessing a signing that didn't occur.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/virginia-election-2020-b0775646f6ca89d5f83106c86de59506|title=Virginia Republicans file suit over McAuliffe's paperwork|date=2021-08-26|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>
=== Debates ===
==== Cancelled debates ====

On July 12, Glenn Youngkin announced he would not take part in the July 24 debate hosted by the [[Virginia Bar Association]] because of a donation made by  one of the moderators, Judy Woodruff.<ref name=apnews.debate1.1>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/government-and-politics-election-2020-522265ba9fd99fc0e96ce67c68c52cec|title=Youngkin declines debate in part over moderator Woodruff|date=2021-07-12|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref><ref name=wsls.debate1.1>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsls.com/news/politics/2021/07/12/glenn-youngkin-not-participating-in-gubernatorial-debate-in-hot-springs-agrees-to-three-others/|title=Glenn Youngkin not participating in gubernatorial debate in Hot Springs, agrees to three others|date=2021-07-12|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> Woodruff had made a $250 donation to the [[Clinton Foundation]] relief fund after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]]. The foundation is run by [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary]] and [[Bill Clinton]], who are close allies to Terry McAuliffe.<ref name=apnews.debate1.1/> On July 28, after discovering that Youngkin would participate in an 'election integrity' rally at [[Liberty University]], McAuliffe declined a debate at the same university.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.virginiascope.com/mcauliffes-campaign-says-he-is-declining-the-liberty-debate-due-to-youngkins-participation-in-election-integrity-rally/|title=McAuliffe's campaign says he is declining the Liberty/Hampton debate due to Youngkin's participation in election integrity rally|date=2021-07-28|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> On August 2, Youngkin declined participation in The People's Debate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wtop.com/virginia/2021/08/youngkin-declines-va-gubernatorial-the-peoples-debate-event-canceled/|title=Youngkin declines Va. gubernatorial 'The People's Debate,' event canceled|date=2021-08-02|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> The two candidates pledged to two debates; one on September 16 and one on September 28.<ref name=nbcdebate.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/virginia-governor-candidates-mcauliffe-youngkin-face-first-debate-n1279327|title=Virginia governor candidates McAuliffe, Youngkin to face off in first debate|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>
==== First debate ====

Youngkin and McAuliffe met at [[Appalachian School of Law]] in [[Grundy, Virginia]] on September 16, 2021, one day before early voting began.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wset.com/news/local/mcauliffe-vs-youngkin-heres-what-you-missed-thursday-nights-debate-glenn-terry-virginia-governor|title=McAuliffe vs. Youngkin: Here's what you missed from Thursday night's debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref> The debate was hosted by [[USA Today]] Washington Bureau Chief, [[Susan Page]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wset.com/news/beyond-the-podium/terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-face-off-thursday-september-16-2021-grundy-southwest-virginia-gubernatorial-debate|title=McAuliffe, Youngkin face-off tonight in first Virginia gubernatorial debate|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>

The debate started with discussion over a recent [[COVID-19 vaccination#Vaccine mandates|COVID-19 mandate]] President [[Joe Biden]] signed requiring federal workers, employees of large companies, and contractors to be vaccinated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/live-updates/biden-covid-19-vaccine-mandates-announcement/|title=Biden announces COVID-19 vaccine mandates that will affect 100 million Americans|date=2021-09-10|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref><ref name=cbs.debate1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-debate-virginia-gubernatorial-race/|title=Vaccine mandates and abortion bans fuel Virginia's first gubernatorial race debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-17|last=Navarro|first=Aaron}}</ref> Youngkin doubted if Biden had the power to authorize the mandate, and supported personal choice for receiving the vaccine. McAuliffe supported the mandate and accused Youngkin of spreading [[COVID-19 misinformation|"anti-vax" rhetoric]].<ref name=cbs.debate1/> Youngkin denied the claim.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/> McAuliffe also supported requiring vaccines for students over the age of 12.<ref name=cnn.debate2>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/16/politics/mcauliffe-youngkin-virginia-governor-debate/index.html|title=McAuliffe and Youngkin spar over Covid vaccine requirements in first Virginia debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-23|last1=Warren|first1=Michael|last2=Merica|first2=Dan}}</ref>

The discussion moved to [[climate change]], where Youngkin stated he would use all sources of energy to address climate change without "putting [the] entire energy grid at risk for political purposes." McAuliffe called for [[clean energy]] in the state by 2035 and stressed the idea for the state to be a production hub.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/>

The discussion then moved to abortion, specifically the recent [[Texas Heartbeat Act]] signed by Texas Governor [[Greg Abbott]] (whom endorsed Youngkin).<ref name=abc.debate1>{{Cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/mcauliffe-youngkin-spar-vision-commonwealth-1st-va-gubernatorial/story?id=80057575|title=McAuliffe, Youngkin spar over vision for commonwealth in 1st Va. gubernatorial debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref> When asked whether or not Youngkin would sign a similar bill, Youngkin stated that he would not sign the bill, and that he was pro-life and supports exclusions in cases such as rape, incest, and when the life of the mother is endangered and also supports a "pain-threshold" bill that would ban most abortions at the point when a fetus can feel pain, which proponents of this type of law define as 20 weeks.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/> In addition, Youngkin stated McAuliffe was "the most extreme pro-abortion candidate in America today".<ref name=abc.debate1/> In response to Youngkin, McAuliffe stated he was a "brick wall" to women's rights and would protect a woman's decision over abortion and supports reducing the number of doctors needed to certify a third-trimester abortion from three to one.<ref name=abc.debate1/>

The next discussion topic was over election integrity. After supporting an "Election Integrity Taskforce", Youngkin stated he does not believe there has been "significant fraud", and stated the issue of fraud as "a democracy issue". Youngkin stressed that he believes that "Joe Biden's our president" and criticized the [[Withdrawal of the United States troops from Afghanistan (2020–2021)|withdrawal from Afghanistan]]. McAuliffe took note to Donald Trump's endorsement of Youngkin, calling him a "Trump wannabe".<ref name=cbs.debate1/> Both candidates stated they would concede the election if the other came out on top.<ref name=abc.debate1/>

The final discussion topic was over the economy. McAuliffe attacked Youngkin on his top economic advisor, [[Stephen Moore (writer)|Stephen Moore]], who advised [[Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign]]. Youngkin defended Virginia's [[right-to-work law]].<ref name=abc.debate1/>
==== Second debate ====

Youngkin and McAuliffe met at the [[Northern Virginia Chamber of Commerce]] on September 28, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.cvent.com/event/5e9837a7-3094-4e39-9659-df9d79321875/summary|access-date=2021-09-23|title=Top of the Ticket 2021 Gubernatorial Debate}}</ref> The event was hosted by [[Chuck Todd]], moderator of [[NBC]]'s ''[[Meet the Press]]''. Less than a week before the debate, one of the panelists, [[Michael Fauntroy]], withdrew from the debate after tweets against the [[GOP]] and [[Evangelicalism|Evangelicals]] were found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/mcauliffe-youngkin-debate-michael-fauntroy|title=Panelist withdraws from upcoming McAuliffe-Youngkin debate after tweets attacking GOP, evangelicals surface|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-09-23|last=Wulfsohn|first=Joseph}}</ref>

On the discussion topic of COVID-19, Youngkin and McAuliffe reiterated their stances on the vaccines. Youngkin stated he believed in mandates for vaccines for diseases [[measles]], [[mumps]] and [[rubella]], but not for COVID-19, saying the "the data associated with those vaccines is something that we should absolutely understand the difference between this vaccine."<ref name=cnn.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/28/politics/virginia-governor-debate-covid-vaccine-mandate/index.html|title=McAuliffe and Youngkin battle over Covid-19 vaccine mandates in Virginia governor's debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> Youngkin said people should get vaccinated against COVID-19.<ref name=cnn.debate2.1/>

During the debate, Youngkin noted that Trump was regularly mentioned by McAuliffe, who again called Youngkin a "Trump wannabe".<ref name=cnn.debate2.1/><ref name=nbc4.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/politics/first-read-dmv/debate-takeaways-virginia-candidates-on-attack-from-start/2815808/|title=Virginia Gubernatorial Candidates on Attack From Start in Debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> When asked, Youngkin stated he would support Trump if he were to become the Republican nominee in [[2024 United States presidential election|2024]].<ref name=nbc4.debate2.1/>

Approximately 15 minutes into the debate, [[Third party (United States)|third party]] candidate Princess Blanding, who was in the audience, disrupted the debate, yelling that her exclusion from the debate was “unfair” and claiming that McAuliffe would not win the election.<ref name=fox.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/nbc-chuck-todd-princess-blanding-terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-debate|title=NBC's Chuck Todd calls for security as third-party Virginia candidate disrupts McAuliffe-Youngkin debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> After being escorted out by security, she claimed that being excluded from the debate was racist and sexist, and that it constituted "censorship".<ref name=hill.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/574407-vaccines-abortion-trump-dominate-final-virginia-governors-debate|title=Vaccines, abortion, Trump dominate final Virginia governor's debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref>

===Debates===

A debate between the five candidates took place on April 6, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.progress-index.com/story/news/2021/04/05/virginia-state-university-chosen-host-upcoming-gubernatorial-democratic-debate/7092418002/|title=Virginia State University chosen to host upcoming gubernatorial Democratic debate|date=2021-04-05|access-date=2021-04-22}}</ref> Lieutenant Governor Justin Fairfax compared scrutiny of his sexual assault allegations to that of the cases of [[George Floyd]] and [[Emmett Till]] in the debate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-democratic-governors-debate/2021/04/06/09221eac-96e0-11eb-962b-78c1d8228819_story.html|title=Justin Fairfax criticized for comparison to George Floyd, Emmett Till at debate|date=2021-04-07|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Schneider|first=Gregory}}</ref>

==Republican convention==

The Republican nomination process for the 2021 elections was the subject of a lengthy and acrimonious debate within the [[Republican Party of Virginia]].<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-gop-governor-vote-counting/2021/04/21/fbb6760c-a2d6-11eb-a774-7b47ceb36ee8_story.html Three Republicans running for Virginia governor wary of vote-counting software], ''Washington Post'' (April 21, 2021).</ref><ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn>{{Cite web|title=Virginia GOP settles on nominating method with May convention looming|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/virginia-gop-settles-on-nominating-method-with-may-convention-looming/|date=April 22, 2021|author=Dean Mirshahi|publisher=WRIC}}</ref> On December 5, 2020, the state Republican Party voted to hold a convention instead of a primary by a vote of 41 to 28.<ref>{{Cite web|title=RPV State Central Committee Meeting;Voted Convention for 2021;Live Updates – Bearing Drift|url=https://bearingdrift.com/2020/12/05/rpv-state-central-committee-meeting-voted-convention-for-2021/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=bearingdrift.com|date=December 5, 2020}}</ref> State Senator [[Amanda Chase]] initially indicated that she would run as an independent,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|last1=Oliver|first1=Ned|date=2020-12-05|title=Chase promises to run as independent for governor after Va. GOP opts for convention over primary|url=https://www.virginiamercury.com/2020/12/05/chase-threatens-to-run-as-independent-for-governor-as-va-gop-opts-for-convention-over-primary/|access-date=2020-12-05|website=Virginia Mercury|language=en-US}}</ref> but later decided to seek nomination at the convention. (However, on the day of the convention, she acknowledged that if she did not win the nomination, she may reconsider and run as an independent, although she eventually decided against this.)<ref>{{cite tweet |last=Chase |first=Amanda |author-link=Amanda Chase |user=AmandaChaseVA |number=1391150084377677826 |date=May 8, 2021 |title=If RPV steals this election for Pete I still have plenty of time to run as an independent. Clear corruption by RPV, I will not honor a pledge if the Party cannot run a fair process. |language=en |access-date=June 12, 2021 |archive-url= |archive-date=June 12, 2021 |url-status=live}}</ref> Faced with pressure from the Chase campaign and activists to return to a primary, the state committee debated scrapping the convention on January 23, 2021. These efforts were unsuccessful and the party reaffirmed their decision to hold a convention.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Oliver |first1=Ned |title=Virginia Republicans stick with nominating convention |url=https://www.virginiamercury.com/2021/01/24/virginia-republicans-stick-with-convention-as-messy-fight-continues/ |access-date=January 25, 2021 |work=Virginia Mercury |date=January 24, 2021}}</ref> On February 9, 2021, the Chase campaign sued the Republican Party of Virginia, arguing that the convention is illegal under [[COVID-19]]-related executive orders signed by Governor [[Ralph Northam]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Manchester|first1=Julia|date=February 9, 2021|title=Republican gubernatorial candidate sues Virginia GOP over nominating process|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/538075-republican-state-senator-sues-virginia-gop-over-nominating-process|url-status=live|access-date=February 9, 2021|website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]}}</ref> The Richmond Circuit Court dismissed the Chase campaign's lawsuit on February 19, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Manzanares|first1=Keyris|date=February 19, 2021|title=Judge blocks Sen. Amanda Chase's lawsuit challenging Virginia GOP nomination plans|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/judge-blocks-sen-amanda-chases-lawsuit-challenging-virginia-gop-nomination-plansw|url-status=live|access-date=February 19, 2021|website=[[WRIC-TV|WRIC]]}}</ref> The Republican Party of Virginia announced on March 26, 2021, that seven gubernatorial candidates had qualified to appear on the convention ballot.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|date=2021-03-26|title=RPV Announces Qualified Convention Candidates|url=https://virginia.gop/rpv-announces-qualified-convention-candidates/|access-date=2021-03-26|website=Republican Party of Virginia|language=en-US}}</ref> On April 11, 2021, the state Republican Party Rules Committee voted to tabulate the ballots by hand; three days later, however, the committee reversed itself and decided to use a vendor's software-based tabulation method.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/>

On April 20, 2021, five candidates (Amanda Chase, Kirk Cox, Sergio de la Peña, Peter Doran, and Glenn Youngkin) participated in a forum at [[Liberty University]] in [[Lynchburg, Virginia|Lynchburg]].<ref name=wric.nom>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/5-republicans-in-virginia-governors-race-make-their-pitch-to-voters-during-liberty-university-forum/|title=Key takeaways from the Republican gubernatorial forum in Lynchburg|date=2021-04-20|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Mirshahi|first=Dean}}</ref> Two candidates, Octavia Johnson and Pete Snyder, did not attend the forum.<ref name=wric.nom/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/republicans-running-for-virginia-governor-appear-at-liberty-university-forum/2021/04/20/b94d408e-a1eb-11eb-a7ee-949c574a09ac_story.html|title=Republicans running for Virginia governor appear at Liberty University forum|date=2021-04-20|access-date=2021-04-22|last=Vozzella|first=Laura}}</ref>

The state Republican convention to select the party's nominees for governor, lieutenant governor, and attorney general took place on May 8, 2021,<ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn/><ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> in "unassembled" format,<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> with ballots to be cast remotely at up to 37 locations statewide<ref name=MirshahiSettlesOn/> using [[instant-runoff voting|ranked-choice voting]].<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> The complex process fueled internal party disputes.<ref name=VozzellaUnorthodox>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-gop-convention/2021/04/04/4bfe8fc4-9228-11eb-a74e-1f4cf89fd948_story.html Unorthodox Republican contest for Virginia governor breeds confusion, suspicion], ''Washington Post'' (April 4, 2021).</ref> Up to 40,000 people were anticipated to become delegates, although not all would necessarily cast votes.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/> Local Republican Party leaders control the application process to become a delegate, decide who can participate (voter registration in Virginia does not include a space to indicate party affiliation), and select the convention voting site.<ref name=VozzellaUnorthodox/> In the preceding Virginia Republican gubernatorial convention, 12,000 participated.<ref name=VozzellaWaryOf/>

[[Orthodox Jewish]] Virginia Republicans asked the party to allow absentee voting for religious reasons (May 8 is on the [[Jewish Sabbath]]), but the State Central Committee initially voted down the request, failing to achieve the 75% supermajority needed to change the rules.<ref>Laura Vozzella, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/virginia-republican-convention-orthodox-jews/2021/04/23/3169c904-a442-11eb-85fc-06664ff4489d_story.html Virginia GOP won't let Orthodox Jews vote absentee in Sabbath-day convention], ''Washington Post'' (April 23, 2021).</ref> However, the Virginia GOP ultimately reversed course and allowed those with religious objections to vote in the May 8 convention via absentee ballots. Republican candidates Kirk Cox, Peter Doran, and Glenn Youngkin had criticized the previous decision to not accommodate Orthodox Jews.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wric.com/news/politics/capitol-connection/in-reversal-virginia-gop-will-allow-those-with-religious-obligations-to-vote-absentee-in-may-8-convention/|title=In reversal, Virginia GOP will allow those with religious obligations to vote absentee in May 8 convention|date=April 26, 2021}}</ref>

==General election==

On August 26, the Republican Party of Virginia filed a lawsuit to disqualify McAuliffe from appearing on the ballot in November. The suit alleges that McAuliffe did not sign his declaration of candidacy, which is needed to qualify in the primary and general election.<ref name=vgop.lawsuit>{{Cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/virginia-republican-party-terry-mcauliffe-lawsuit-governor-ballot-signature-2021-8|title=Virginia GOP files lawsuit to remove Democratic gubernatorial nominee Terry McAuliffe from the November ballot|date=2021-08-28|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> It was found that the declaration of candidacy was missing his signature, although it includes two witnesses' signatures. The suit also alleges the witnesses violated state law by witnessing a signing that didn't occur.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://apnews.com/article/virginia-election-2020-b0775646f6ca89d5f83106c86de59506|title=Virginia Republicans file suit over McAuliffe's paperwork|date=2021-08-26|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>
=== Debates ===
==== Cancelled debates ====

On July 12, Glenn Youngkin announced he would not take part in the July 24 debate hosted by the [[Virginia Bar Association]] because of a donation made by  one of the moderators, Judy Woodruff.<ref name=apnews.debate1.1>{{Cite web|url=https://apnews.com/article/government-and-politics-election-2020-522265ba9fd99fc0e96ce67c68c52cec|title=Youngkin declines debate in part over moderator Woodruff|date=2021-07-12|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref><ref name=wsls.debate1.1>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wsls.com/news/politics/2021/07/12/glenn-youngkin-not-participating-in-gubernatorial-debate-in-hot-springs-agrees-to-three-others/|title=Glenn Youngkin not participating in gubernatorial debate in Hot Springs, agrees to three others|date=2021-07-12|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> Woodruff had made a $250 donation to the [[Clinton Foundation]] relief fund after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]]. The foundation is run by [[Hillary Clinton|Hillary]] and [[Bill Clinton]], who are close allies to Terry McAuliffe.<ref name=apnews.debate1.1/> On July 28, after discovering that Youngkin would participate in an 'election integrity' rally at [[Liberty University]], McAuliffe declined a debate at the same university.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.virginiascope.com/mcauliffes-campaign-says-he-is-declining-the-liberty-debate-due-to-youngkins-participation-in-election-integrity-rally/|title=McAuliffe's campaign says he is declining the Liberty/Hampton debate due to Youngkin's participation in election integrity rally|date=2021-07-28|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> On August 2, Youngkin declined participation in The People's Debate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://wtop.com/virginia/2021/08/youngkin-declines-va-gubernatorial-the-peoples-debate-event-canceled/|title=Youngkin declines Va. gubernatorial 'The People's Debate,' event canceled|date=2021-08-02|access-date=2021-08-31}}</ref> The two candidates pledged to two debates; one on September 16 and one on September 28.<ref name=nbcdebate.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/virginia-governor-candidates-mcauliffe-youngkin-face-first-debate-n1279327|title=Virginia governor candidates McAuliffe, Youngkin to face off in first debate|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>
==== First debate ====

Youngkin and McAuliffe met at [[Appalachian School of Law]] in [[Grundy, Virginia]] on September 16, 2021, one day before early voting began.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wset.com/news/local/mcauliffe-vs-youngkin-heres-what-you-missed-thursday-nights-debate-glenn-terry-virginia-governor|title=McAuliffe vs. Youngkin: Here's what you missed from Thursday night's debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref> The debate was hosted by [[USA Today]] Washington Bureau Chief, [[Susan Page]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://wset.com/news/beyond-the-podium/terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-face-off-thursday-september-16-2021-grundy-southwest-virginia-gubernatorial-debate|title=McAuliffe, Youngkin face-off tonight in first Virginia gubernatorial debate|date=2021-09-16|access-date=2021-09-16}}</ref>

The debate started with discussion over a recent [[COVID-19 vaccination#Vaccine mandates|COVID-19 mandate]] President [[Joe Biden]] signed requiring federal workers, employees of large companies, and contractors to be vaccinated.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/live-updates/biden-covid-19-vaccine-mandates-announcement/|title=Biden announces COVID-19 vaccine mandates that will affect 100 million Americans|date=2021-09-10|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref><ref name=cbs.debate1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-debate-virginia-gubernatorial-race/|title=Vaccine mandates and abortion bans fuel Virginia's first gubernatorial race debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-17|last=Navarro|first=Aaron}}</ref> Youngkin doubted if Biden had the power to authorize the mandate, and supported personal choice for receiving the vaccine. McAuliffe supported the mandate and accused Youngkin of spreading [[COVID-19 misinformation|"anti-vax" rhetoric]].<ref name=cbs.debate1/> Youngkin denied the claim.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/> McAuliffe also supported requiring vaccines for students over the age of 12.<ref name=cnn.debate2>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/16/politics/mcauliffe-youngkin-virginia-governor-debate/index.html|title=McAuliffe and Youngkin spar over Covid vaccine requirements in first Virginia debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-23|last1=Warren|first1=Michael|last2=Merica|first2=Dan}}</ref>

The discussion moved to [[climate change]], where Youngkin stated he would use all sources of energy to address climate change without "putting [the] entire energy grid at risk for political purposes." McAuliffe called for [[clean energy]] in the state by 2035 and stressed the idea for the state to be a production hub.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/>

The discussion then moved to abortion, specifically the recent [[Texas Heartbeat Act]] signed by Texas Governor [[Greg Abbott]] (whom endorsed Youngkin).<ref name=abc.debate1>{{Cite news|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/mcauliffe-youngkin-spar-vision-commonwealth-1st-va-gubernatorial/story?id=80057575|title=McAuliffe, Youngkin spar over vision for commonwealth in 1st Va. gubernatorial debate|date=2021-09-17|access-date=2021-09-17}}</ref> When asked whether or not Youngkin would sign a similar bill, Youngkin stated that he would not sign the bill, and that he was pro-life and supports exclusions in cases such as rape, incest, and when the life of the mother is endangered and also supports a "pain-threshold" bill that would ban most abortions at the point when a fetus can feel pain, which proponents of this type of law define as 20 weeks.<ref name=nbcdebate.1/> In addition, Youngkin stated McAuliffe was "the most extreme pro-abortion candidate in America today".<ref name=abc.debate1/> In response to Youngkin, McAuliffe stated he was a "brick wall" to women's rights and would protect a woman's decision over abortion and supports reducing the number of doctors needed to certify a third-trimester abortion from three to one.<ref name=abc.debate1/>

The next discussion topic was over election integrity. After supporting an "Election Integrity Taskforce", Youngkin stated he does not believe there has been "significant fraud", and stated the issue of fraud as "a democracy issue". Youngkin stressed that he believes that "Joe Biden's our president" and criticized the [[Withdrawal of the United States troops from Afghanistan (2020–2021)|withdrawal from Afghanistan]]. McAuliffe took note to Donald Trump's endorsement of Youngkin, calling him a "Trump wannabe".<ref name=cbs.debate1/> Both candidates stated they would concede the election if the other came out on top.<ref name=abc.debate1/>

The final discussion topic was over the economy. McAuliffe attacked Youngkin on his top economic advisor, [[Stephen Moore (writer)|Stephen Moore]], who advised [[Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign]]. Youngkin defended Virginia's [[right-to-work law]].<ref name=abc.debate1/>
==== Second debate ====

Youngkin and McAuliffe met at the [[Northern Virginia Chamber of Commerce]] on September 28, 2021.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.cvent.com/event/5e9837a7-3094-4e39-9659-df9d79321875/summary|access-date=2021-09-23|title=Top of the Ticket 2021 Gubernatorial Debate}}</ref> The event was hosted by [[Chuck Todd]], moderator of [[NBC]]'s ''[[Meet the Press]]''. Less than a week before the debate, one of the panelists, [[Michael Fauntroy]], withdrew from the debate after tweets against the [[GOP]] and [[Evangelicalism|Evangelicals]] were found.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/mcauliffe-youngkin-debate-michael-fauntroy|title=Panelist withdraws from upcoming McAuliffe-Youngkin debate after tweets attacking GOP, evangelicals surface|date=2021-09-22|access-date=2021-09-23|last=Wulfsohn|first=Joseph}}</ref>

On the discussion topic of COVID-19, Youngkin and McAuliffe reiterated their stances on the vaccines. Youngkin stated he believed in mandates for vaccines for diseases [[measles]], [[mumps]] and [[rubella]], but not for COVID-19, saying the "the data associated with those vaccines is something that we should absolutely understand the difference between this vaccine."<ref name=cnn.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/28/politics/virginia-governor-debate-covid-vaccine-mandate/index.html|title=McAuliffe and Youngkin battle over Covid-19 vaccine mandates in Virginia governor's debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> Youngkin said people should get vaccinated against COVID-19.<ref name=cnn.debate2.1/>

During the debate, Youngkin noted that Trump was regularly mentioned by McAuliffe, who again called Youngkin a "Trump wannabe".<ref name=cnn.debate2.1/><ref name=nbc4.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/politics/first-read-dmv/debate-takeaways-virginia-candidates-on-attack-from-start/2815808/|title=Virginia Gubernatorial Candidates on Attack From Start in Debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> When asked, Youngkin stated he would support Trump if he were to become the Republican nominee in [[2024 United States presidential election|2024]].<ref name=nbc4.debate2.1/>

Approximately 15 minutes into the debate, [[Third party (United States)|third party]] candidate Princess Blanding, who was in the audience, disrupted the debate, yelling that her exclusion from the debate was “unfair” and claiming that McAuliffe would not win the election.<ref name=fox.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxnews.com/media/nbc-chuck-todd-princess-blanding-terry-mcauliffe-glenn-youngkin-debate|title=NBC's Chuck Todd calls for security as third-party Virginia candidate disrupts McAuliffe-Youngkin debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref> After being escorted out by security, she claimed that being excluded from the debate was racist and sexist, and that it constituted "censorship".<ref name=hill.debate2.1>{{Cite news|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/574407-vaccines-abortion-trump-dominate-final-virginia-governors-debate|title=Vaccines, abortion, Trump dominate final Virginia governor's debate|date=2021-09-28|access-date=2021-09-29}}</ref>

title: 2021 Virginia gubernatorial election
added: The 2021 Virginia gubernatorial election was won by Glenn Youngkin in an enormous upset. For months, the liberal mainstream media had said the Virginia would never vote for a Republican and that Creepy Clintonite Terry McAuliffe would win in a rout, but they had no idea how much BACKLASH and OUTRAGE the Democrat party had stirred. All over the great Commonwealth, people were fed up with the far-left agenda of Joe Biden, the most unpopular and hated president in American history. While Joe and Terry were pushing Critical Race Theory, Virginians realized that Democrat socialist policies had wrecked the economy, skyrocketed inflation, and created shortages of anything and everything. Then, in an act of total desperation, Terry and his campaign disgracefully tried to slander Glenn Youngkin as a Neo-Nazi. The people of Virginia were not fooled by these lies, however, and Glenn won BIG, proving that a massive RED WAVE had begun for Republicans across the country!
